entry.title: Minecraft Login Problems Note
entry.content:
English

I encountered a login issue while playing GTNH (a Minecraft modpack). Although I successfully logged into my official account through the PCL launcher, I was unable to join any servers with authentication enabled — the game consistently displayed the message “Login failed: Authentication servers are down for maintenance.”

Most online solutions suggested modifying the hosts file, refreshing the DNS cache, re-logging into the account, or enabling multiplayer mode in the Microsoft account settings. However, none of these methods worked for me. Even after switching to a different launcher, the problem persisted.

Eventually, I discovered that the issue was caused by Java. PCL had automatically downloaded Java 8 for GTNH, but for some reason it failed to connect properly. In this case, the launcher displayed “OAuth: Offline” in the upper left corner. Even after the browser reported a successful login, the status remained offline.

After switching to Java 25, the issue was resolved. The upper-left indicator now correctly shows “OAuth: Logged in.”

中文

我在登录 GTNH（一个 Minecraft 整合包）时遇到了一些问题。虽然我已经通过 PCL 启动器成功登录了正版账号，但在尝试加入任何开启正版验证的服务器时，始终提示：“登入失败：身份验证目前正在停机维护。”

网上常见的解决方法包括修改 Hosts 文件、刷新 DNS、重新登录账号，以及在XBOX&微软账户中启用多人模式。然而，我在逐一尝试后依然无法解决问题。即使更换启动器，情况也没有改善。

最终我发现问题出在 Java 上。PCL 为 GTNH 自动下载了 Java 8，但由于某些原因，它无法正确建立身份验证连接。此时启动器左上角会显示 “OAuth：离线”。即便浏览器中提示登录成功，状态依然保持离线。

当我将 Java 版本更换为 Java 25 后，问题立刻得到解决。此时左上角显示为 “OAuth：登录”，可以正常进入服务器。

entry.title: PHY 162a Note 3 - Integral of the Equation of Motion
PHY 162a Note Preface
entry.content:
Introduction

This category, PHY 162a Note, contains my personal notes for the Quantum Mechanics course at Brandeis University.
You may use these notes as a reference. If you notice any mistakes, please feel free to contact me at suwako2524@gmail.com.

I use Курс теоретической физики (Course of Theoretical Physics) by Landau and Lifshitz for Quantum Mechanics.

Contents

I. Mechanics

  1. Mechanics 1: Motion Equation
  2. Mechanics 2: Conservation Law
  3. Mechanics 3: Integral of the Equation of Motion

II. Field Theory

III. Quantum Mechanics

entry.title: 0.5. Check List
entry.content:
Check List

This checklist is designed for new members joining the CCATS Group. It helps you verify that all required servers and software are properly configured before starting any computational work.

1. Supercomputers

In the CCATS group, we primarily use two clusters: PETE and OSCER, hosted respectively by Oklahoma State University (OSU) and the University of Oklahoma (OU). These two clusters are largely interchangeable. For example, if PETE is under maintenance, you can usually submit your jobs to OSCER instead.

However, due to differences in system architecture and software environments, the recommended usage is as follows:

  • PETE: for CPU-based tasks
    (e.g., Q-Chem quantum chemistry calculations, classical molecular dynamics simulations)
  • OSCER: for GPU-based tasks
    (e.g., machine learning, QM/MM simulations)

Account Request

You can use the following link to apply:

PETE: https://hpcc.okstate.edu/account-request.html
OSCER: https://www.ou.edu/oscer/support/accounts/new_account

Before applying, inform Dr. Shao that you plan to request an account.
Typically, your account will be approved within one week.
Do not apply from outside the United States.

group name: ccats

The 4 digit pin: choose the numbers you like(and can remember)

If you encounter any issues during registration or setup, please ask other group members for assistance.

2. IQmol

Our group primarily performs quantum chemical calculations using Q-Chem. You do not need to install Q-Chem locally, since we maintain multiple customized versions on the supercomputers for method development.
If you need access to a specific version, please ask one of the group members.

If you are a graduate student who plans to compile or modify Q-Chem yourself, refer to the section
Q-Chem Basic
for detailed instructions on downloading, compiling, and configuring Q-Chem.

2.1 Installing IQmol

To visualize Q-Chem results, you should install IQmol on your personal computer (Windows or macOS recommended).
If you plan to run molecular dynamics simulations, you may also need VMD for trajectory visualization.

Unless you are very familiar with Linux, it is better to use Windows or macOS for your local setup.

You can download IQmol from its official website:
https://www.iqmol.org/

Download the latest version, extract the archive, and install it following the on-screen instructions.

2.2 Verification Checklist

After installation, please verify that:

  1. IQmol launches normally.
  2. You can build a molecule using the graphical interface.
  3. You can save the molecule file correctly.
  4. You can open and visualize Q-Chem output files.

For more detailed guidance, see the dedicated section:
IQmol

2.3 Known Issues

macOS security warning:
On macOS, IQmol may show a warning that the developer’s certificate cannot be verified.
To fix this, go to System Preferences → Security & Privacy, and allow IQmol to run.

macOS File saving issue:
Some macOS users have reported that IQmol cannot save files properly.
Installing an older version of IQmol may resolve this issue.

If you encounter other installation or runtime problems, searching through Google or ChatGPT(or other AI) can help you find effective solutions.

3. Server Access and File Transfer (Optional)

Since PETE and OSCER are remote computing clusters, you need to access them through SSH or similar remote connection methods. In principle, you can use CMD or PowerShell on Windows, or the command line on macOS or Linux, to connect to the servers and use the scp command for file transfer.

However, for beginners, using the command line for all operations can be inconvenient and may take some time to become familiar with. Therefore, it is recommended to use dedicated software tools to simplify these tasks.

For Windows users:
XShell: remote server access and command-line operations.
Xftp or WinSCP: file transfer between your local computer and the server.

For macOS users:
FileZilla: file transfer between your local computer and the server.

These tools provide a graphical interface that makes connecting to remote servers and managing files much easier.

3.1 Basic SSH and SCP Examples

If you prefer using the command line directly, below are some common examples for connecting to and transferring files with the supercomputers.

SSH Login

Use the following command to log in to the PETE or OSCER cluster:

or

After entering the command, you will be prompted to input your password(the password will not display when typing). Once connected, you will enter the remote Linux shell, where you can submit jobs, edit scripts, or monitor your calculations.
File Upload (from local to server)

Use the scp command to upload a file or directory to the remote cluster:

Upload an entire directory:

File Download (from server to local)

Copy files from the server back to your local machine:

This command downloads the file output.out from the server into your current local directory.

entry.title: Q-Chem Basic
entry.content:
Basic of Q-chem

Q-Chem is a general-purpose electronic-structure package maintained and distributed by Q-Chem, Inc., headquartered in Pleasanton, California (USA). Founded in 1993, it is developed by a broad community of contributors. Within the CCATS group, Q-Chem serves as the primary platform for method development and production calculations.

1.Q-Chem overview

Q-Chem is a general-purpose electronic-structure package offering broad coverage from HF/DFT to advanced correlated and multireference methods. As of August 23, 2025, the latest release is Q-Chem 6.3.

Core capabilities (selected)

  1. Ground-state SCF (HF/ROHF/UHF): analytic gradients/Hessians, robust optimizers, and property analysis.
  2. Density Functional Theory: semilocal → double-hybrid functionals; energies, geometry optimizations, and vibrational analyses; TDDFT including spin-flip variants for challenging excitations.
  3. Post-HF correlation: MP2 family (incl. OO/RI/dual-basis, MP3), coupled-cluster (CCSD, CCSD(T)) and a wide EOM-CC suite (EE/SF/IP/EA), plus ADC methods.
  4. Strong correlation & active-space options: CASSCF/CAS-CI, RAS-CI/RAS-SF, CCVB/PP, and spin-flip DFT.
  5. Excited states (broad toolbox): CIS, CIS(D), TDDFT/SF-TDDFT, ΔSCF via MOM/SGM, NOCI/NOCIS, EOM-CC, ADC; support for core-level excitations (CVS).
  6. Embedding & extended systems: stand-alone QM/MM, CHARMM interface, QM/EFP, and modern dielectric/embedding models.
  7. PES exploration & optimization: constrained and unconstrained optimizations (minima/TS), IRC paths, and relaxed scans.

Performance & parallelism
Q-Chem supports OpenMP threading, MPI for distributed-memory runs. Usually one should run with 2n numbers of cores. I ran some benchmark of the parallel jobs:

Figure 1. Parallel benchmarking of Q-Chem on the test molecule. Three tasks(single-point (SP), force, and vibrational frequency) were run with 2, 4, 8, 16, and 32 CPU cores on PETE. Speedup is computed from wall time relative to the 2-core run. According to the Figure, adding more cores won’t give proportional speeds.

2. Install & Compile Q-chem

Requirements:

  • An access to a Linux Computer
  • Q-chem package
  • Basic knowledge of the Linux shell & Slurm

Optional:

  • Pete supercomputer (used as an example in this tutorial)
  • Q-chem developer access

If you plan to develop new features in Q-Chem (e.g., new functions, special requirements), or if you simply want your own installation, you’ll need to download and compile Q-Chem in your home environment.

2.1: Download Q-Chem

Select a suitable directory for Q-Chem that has enough space (at least 10 GB) and will not be automatically cleaned up by system administrators.

On the Pete supercomputer, a recommended location is/scratch/$user/software/ .

Replace $user with your own username. If the software directory does not exist, create it with:

You can use pwd to verify that you are inside /scratch/$user/software.

For Q-Chem developers, you can check out the latest source code via SVN:

Replace $qchem-developer-id with your developer ID and $qchem-directory-name with a custom name for your Q-Chem installation.
If you just want a standard installation, you can simply use qchem as the folder name:

The download may take some time. After it finishes, you should see a new folder with the name you specified. Change into this directory, and prepare to configure the build.

2.2 Compile Q-Chem

On the Pete supercomputer, you can write the following script (compiler.sh) to set up the environment and configure Q-Chem:

Source the script to start configuration:

The terminal should display progress messages. If everything is set up correctly, you will see:

Configureing done

Generating done

Build files have been written to: /scratch/$USER/software/qchem/build

This indicates that the build directory has been created successfully.

If you encounter errors, check the output and carefully read the error messages. In most cases, problems can be resolved by installing the required module, searching for the error message on Google or by asking ChatGPT for help.

There’re some collection for [Known Issues](./Q-Chem Compile Issues.md).

Copy the compiler.sh file into build directory

Edit the copied script by adding one more line at the end:

This will build Q-Chem with 16 parallel threads and save the compilation output into mall.log.

Use the following command to submit the compile command.

The first compilation can usually take more than 4 hours.

To check whether the job is still running or has finished (successfully or with errors), use:

You can also check the build logs in:

When compilation finishes successfully, a file named qcprog.exe will appear in either the build directory or the exe directory.

If the executable is located in the build directory, copy it to your designated exe folder, for example:

At this point, you have successfully compiled Q-Chem.

3. File structure of Q-chem input file

Q-Chem input files are divided into several modules, each enclosed by $… and $end.
Below is an example input file, followed by explanations of the most commonly used sections:

3.1 $molecule

The molecule block specifies the atomic structure, charge, and spin multiplicity of the system:

The first line after $molecule contains:

  • Charge (here 0, meaning neutral molecule)
  • Multiplicity (here 1, meaning a singlet state, in which all electrons are paired)

The following lines list each atom:

  • Element symbol (e.g., O, H)
  • Cartesian coordinates in Ångström (x, y, z).

This block defines both the electronic state and the geometry of your system.

3.2 $rem

The $rem block (short for run-time environment module) controls most of the calculation settings in Q-Chem.

Here’s what each line means:

  • BASIS = 6-31+G\*
    • Specifies the basis set.
    • 6-31+G* is a split-valence basis set with diffuse (+) and polarization (*) functions.
    • You can change this to other basis sets (e.g., cc-pVDZ, def2-TZVP).
  • JOB_TYPE = opt
    • Defines the type of calculation.
    • Common options:
      • sp → single-point energy
      • opt → geometry optimization
      • freq → vibrational frequency analysis
      • force → analytic gradient
  • METHOD = HF
    • Specifies the electronic structure method.
    • Examples:
      • HF (Hartree–Fock)
      • DFT functionals (e.g., B3LYP, PBE0)
      • MP2, CCSD, ADC, etc.
  • SOLVENT_METHOD = PCM
    • Tells Q-Chem to include solvent effects using the Polarizable Continuum Model (PCM).
    • Requires an additional $solvent block. It specific which solvent you are using by their dielectric value.

The $rem section is the heart of the input file, it controls what calculation is being done and how. A significant thing is that, whenever you copy an input file from others, and you don’t know exactly each line means.

4. Run a Q-Chem job

Once you have Q-Chem installed, run a few small jobs to test it. (You can also borrow a working Q-Chem install on a shared server to practice job submission.)

We usually keep each project in its own folder—don’t mix everything together (unless you’re a T-800 ).

Tip: press Tab for filename autocompletion.

You can either copy the example input file in section 3, or create your own one. I give the example input name as H2O2.inp. Just use the following command

In vi: press a to enter insert mode, paste example input from Section 3, press Esc, then type :wq to save and quit.

usually we use bash to submit jobs. Still create a file named sub.sh. You can just use the following bash first:

Why these settings?

  • --ntasks=1 + --cpus-per-task=16 is the correct layout for threaded (OpenMP) Q-Chem runs.
  • qchem -nt N tells Q-Chem to use N OpenMP threads.

Submit the job (from the folder containing H2O2.inp and sub.sh):

Useful Slurm command:

5. View Q-Chem Results with IQmol

entry.title: Quantum Chemistry Theory Basic
entry.content:
Quantum Chemistry Theory Basic

Note: This part is for a quick introduction to Quantum Chemistry. For a more comprehensive study, I recommend Modern Quantum Chemistry by Szabo.

Quantum chemistry calculations face the central challenge of solving the Schrödinger equation for many-body systems. Because the Schrödinger equation is too complex to be solved exactly, in practical numerical calculations various approximations are always introduced to reduce computational complexity and cost. Common approximations include:

  • Born–Oppenheimer approximation
  • Finite basis set approximation
  • Single-electron approximation, electron correlation approximations
  • Relativistic approximations
  • Approximations in numerical accuracy of computation

In most cases, the accuracy of quantum chemistry calculations depends critically on two aspects: the theoretical method and the basis set.

I. Born–Oppenheimer (BO) Approximation

To rigorously solve the Schrödinger equation of a molecular system, both electrons and nuclei must be treated quantum mechanically, which makes the problem very complex:

H^totΨtot(R;r)=EtotΨtot(R;r)

Since nuclear masses are much larger than electron masses, quantum effects of nuclei are much smaller than those of electrons. The BO approximation is one of the most important approximations in quantum chemistry. It separates nuclear and electronic motions, thereby reducing the complexity of solving the molecular Schrödinger equation:

Ψtot(R;r)=Ψnuc(R)Ψele(R)(r)

1.1 Electronic Schrödinger Equation

Under the BO approximation, when solving the electronic wavefunction, the nuclear positions are regarded as fixed parameters. Thus, the BO approximation is also referred to as the fixed-nuclei approximation.

For each set of nuclear coordinates R , the corresponding electronic energy Eele(R) can be obtained by solving the electronic Schrödinger equation. This energy is called the potential energy or potential energy surface (PES) under the BO approximation:

H^ele(R)Ψele(R)(r)=Eele(R)Ψele(R)(r)

To describe nuclear motion, one must further solve the nuclear Schrödinger equation, which includes the nuclear kinetic energy operator and the interaction potential:

[T^nuc+Epot(R)]Ψnuc(R)=EtotΨnuc(R)

1.2 Beyond the BO Approximation

For directly solving the nuclear + electronic system, using the BO approximation to obtain the nuclear wavefunction and Etot , the following corrections may be introduced:

  1. Non-adiabatic correction: This introduces the non-adiabatic coupling matrix elements (NACME), which describe the coupling between different electronic states and nuclear motion.
  2. Diagonal correction: The diagonal part corresponding to NACME, used to correct the coupling between a single electronic state and nuclear motion; this contribution is usually small.
  3. Mass polarization correction: Arising from the coupling between the internal motion of the electrons and the center-of-mass motion of the nuclei.

For details, see Introduction to Computational Chemistry (3rd edition), Section 3.1.

1.3 Diagonal Born–Oppenheimer Correction (DBOC)

When no strong intersection of two potential energy surfaces occurs, the BO approximation is often very reasonable. Errors in the electronic part of the calculation are mainly due to the neglect of nuclear motion. If further corrections are required, one can add the Diagonal Born–Oppenheimer Correction (DBOC) to the electronic energy:

ΔEDBOC=∑Aatoms−12MA⟨Ψele|∇A2|Ψele⟩

In molecular dynamics simulations involving nuclear motion, potential energy surfaces alone are not sufficient; one must also consider the coupling between electronic and nuclear motion. The non-adiabatic coupling matrix elements (NACME) then become particularly important. In such cases, although the BO approximation provides a useful starting point, the electronic Schrödinger equation must often be solved repeatedly with explicit inclusion of NACME terms.

II. Electron Correlation

In practical quantum chemical calculations, the molecular Hamiltonian is written as:

H^ele(R)=∑i[−12∇i2−∑AZA|ri−RA|]+∑i>j1rij+∑A>BZAZB|RA−RB|

where the terms correspond to electron kinetic energy, electron–nucleus attraction, electron–electron repulsion, and nucleus–nucleus repulsion. The first bracketed part is the one-electron part.

2.1 Electron–Electron Interaction in Terms of Density

The electron–electron interaction can also be expressed in terms of the electron density, which provides a more intuitive physical picture:

Eee=⟨Ψ|∑i>j1rij|Ψ⟩=∬ρ(r1,r2)r12dr1dr2

The two-particle density can be decomposed as:

ρ(r1,r2)=[ραα(r1,r2)+ρββ(r1,r2)]+[ραβ(r1,r2)+ρβα(r1,r2)]=ρ↑↑(r1,r2)+ρ↑↓(r1,r2)
  • Same-spin pair density ρ↑↑(r1,r2)=Γ↑↑(r1,r2)=ρ↑(r1)ρ↑(r2)+ΓX↑↑(r1,r2)
  • Opposite-spin pair density ρ↑↓(r1,r2)=Γ↑↓(r1,r2)=ρ↑(r1)ρ↓(r2)

2.2 Exchange and Coulomb Correlation

  • Exchange correlation ( X ): Arises from the Pauli exclusion principle (antisymmetry of the electronic wavefunction). This reduces the probability of finding two same-spin electrons close to each other. The corresponding energy lowering is the exchange energy EX .

  • Coulomb correlation ( C ): Due to Coulomb repulsion, electrons tend to avoid each other even beyond exchange effects, lowering the probability of electron–electron co-location. This further reduces the system energy, corresponding to the correlation energy EC .

Thus, electron correlation effects beyond exchange are essential to capture long-range Coulomb avoidance. Approximations neglecting this (e.g., Hartree–Fock) miss correlation energy, which must be included for quantitative accuracy.

Example: H2

Consider the hydrogen molecule:

  • Correlation hole: If one electron is known to be at a certain position, the probability of finding another electron nearby is reduced due to exchange and correlation effects.
  • Fermi hole: Reflects the Pauli principle; the minimum value is 0, showing that the probability of finding two same-spin electrons at the same position is zero.
  • Coulomb hole: Arises from Coulomb repulsion; the distribution shifts slightly to avoid close encounters even for opposite-spin electrons.

Graphically, the total hole can be seen as a combination of the Fermi hole and Coulomb hole, shifting electron density to reduce repulsion.

III. Classification of Common Theoretical Methods

  • Semi-empirical methods (e.g., Semi-empirical, DFTB, GFN-xTB)
  • Density functional theory (DFT)
  • Hartree–Fock (HF)
  • Perturbation theory
  • Coupled cluster (CC)
  • Configuration interaction (CI)
  • Multiconfigurational self-consistent field (MCSCF)
  • Multireference methods (e.g., MRCI, CASPT2)
  • Molecular mechanics (MM, non-quantum chemistry)

Among them, ab initio methods are those derived directly from first principles without empirical parameters. In practice, computational chemistry often balances accuracy and computational cost.

DFT is currently the most widely used method because it achieves a balance between efficiency and accuracy. Although not as rigorous as wavefunction-based post-HF methods, DFT is still a mainstream tool.

entry.title: Single Point Calculation
entry.content:
Single-Point (SP) Calculation

A single-point (SP) calculation evaluates properties (most commonly the electronic energy) of a system at a fixed geometry. It’s the simplest job type in computational chemistry and a building block for scans, optimizations, and higher-level methods.

Where the geometry comes from

  • Manually built in a GUI (e.g., IQmol)
  • From a prior geometry optimization
  • From experiment (X-ray, neutron, cryo-EM models)
  • From supplementary information (SI) in papers
  • Automatically generated by other programs or scripts (ASE, RDKit, Amber, etc.)

What Q-Chem does in a default SP run

  1. Print license banner and echo the input.
  2. Initialize the molecular structure and basis set.
  3. Build an initial guess for the wavefunction and evaluate its energy.
  4. Run self-consistent field (SCF) iterations until converged.
  5. If requested, perform additional models (DFT options, TDDFT roots, post-HF correlation, etc.).
  6. Analyze the wavefunction: orbital energies (HOMO–LUMO), charges, multipole moments, and other requested properties.
  7. Write a summary and timings, then exit.

entry.title: PHY 162a 2
entry.content:
Physics 162a (QM I):

Problem Set 2

1. Constrained Lagrangian systems

Consider a Lagrangian system consisting of D coordinates qI ( I=1,…,D ) and m constraints fa=fa=1,…,m(qI)=0 .
Let si ( i=1,…,D−m ) be coordinates on the constrained submanifold defined by fa(q)=0 , so that fa(qI(si,t))=0 for all si . We showed in class that for any infinitesimal motion δsi , then

(1)(pI−FI)∂qI∂siδsi=0

Show that the equations of motion above follow from the Euler–Lagrange equations for

(2)L~(si,s˙i)=L(qI(si),s˙i∂qI∂si(si)).

2. Non-inertial frames

(a) Consider a system with Lagrangian L[qα,q˙α] which satisfies the Euler–Lagrange equations

(3)ddt∂L∂q˙α−∂L∂qα=0.

Now assume q can be expressed in terms of a different set of coordinates sα via a time-dependent coordinate transformation
qα=qα(s1,…,sm,t) , where α=1,…,m .
Show that L satisfies Lagrange’s equations with respect to the new coordinates sα :

(4)ddt∂L∂s˙α−∂L∂sα=0.

(This should be close to the story for time-independent coordinate changes.)

(b) A bead with mass m is constrained to move on a massless hoop of radius a with a diameter fixed to lie along the z -axis.
The hoop is rotating about the z axis with constant angular speed ω .

i. Lagrangian and equations of motion. Obtain the Lagrangian and the Euler–Lagrange equations of motion assuming that the only external force arises from a constant gravitational force −mgz^ .

ii. Critical angular speed. Show that if ω>ω0 for some particular critical frequency ω0 , there exists a solution in which the particle remains stationary on the hoop at a point other than the bottom (or top), but for ω<ω0 , the only stationary points are the bottom and top. Find this value of ω0 .

Important hints

  • It is worth working in spherical coordinates, with the origin fixed at the center of the hoop, θ the angle from the z axis, and ϕ the azimuthal angle with respect to the x axis. Start with a particle in 3 dimensions (with the gravitational force) in these coordinates, and then impose the constraints.
  • Some of the constraints will be time dependent. Nonetheless, you can still take the resulting time-dependent solution and plug it back into the Lagrangian. The usual Euler–Lagrange equations still follow from stationarity of the action even if the Lagrangian has explicit time dependence.

© Consider a particle moving under the influence of some central force (about the origin).
Write the Lagrangian in a frame that rotates with constant angular velocity Ω=ωz^ about the z axis.
Using the Euler–Lagrange equations, write the equations of motion in this rotating frame, and show that one gets the additional Coriolis and centrifugal force terms:

mx¨=Fcor+Fcentrifugal+F(|x|), (5)Fcor=−2mΩ×x˙,Fcentrifugal=−mΩ×(Ω×x),

and F(|x|) takes the same form as in the non-rotating frame.

entry.title: 0. Preface & Contents
entry.content:
Preface

I’ve been planning to write a series of tutorials for a long time,
but procrastination got the better of me—until now.
This series aims to serve as both a personal notebook and a beginner’s guide
to computational chemistry, covering theory, software usage, and practical coding.

TO DO LIST:

  1. Check List

  2. Computational Chemistry Softwares

    1. Q-Chem Basic
    2. IQmol
    3. Multiwfn
    4. VMD
    5. Pymol
    6. ORCA

  3. Computational Chemistry Jobs

    1. [Quantum Chemistry Theory Basic (quick review version)](/Quantum Chemistry Theory Basic/)
    2. [Basis Set](/Basis Set/)
    3. Single Point
    4. Potential Energy Surface I. Concept
    5. Geometry Optimization
    6. Transition State
    7. IRC and Chemical Reactions
    8. Potential Energy Surface II. Scan
    9. Vibration Analysis, Infrared Spectra, Raman Spectra, VCD and ROA spectra
    10. Thermodynamics
    11. Weak Interactions
    12. Solvent Models
    13. Excited States and Electronic spectra I. Theories
    14. Excited States and Electronic spectra II. Calculations
    15. Miscellaneous

  4. Quantum Chemistry Basic

    1. Quantum Mechanic
    2. Hartree-Fock
    3. CI methods
    4. DFT

  5. Object-Oriented Programming(One should already have python code experience)

    1. Types of Coding

    2. Concept of Objects

    3. Objects and Classes in Python

    4. Example: Jobs Management for Q-Chem by Python

  6. Quantum Chemistry Code Implement

    1. Hartree-Fock
    2. DFT?
    3. FCI?
    4. First Order Gradient
    5. Hessian

  7. Other things

entry.title: PHY 162a 1
entry.content:
Physics 162a (QM I)

Problem Set 1

1. Consider the following Lagrangian

L=12gαβ(q)q˙αq˙β

with α,β=1,…,d , where gαβ is called a metric, and has an inverse gαβ such that

gαβgβρ=δρα.

Here δ is the Kronecker delta function, and the Einstein summation convention is used.

You may apply the Euler–Lagrange equations as before:

∂L∂qα−ddt∂L∂q˙α=0

(a)

Write the generalized momenta and the generalized forces.

(b)

Show that the Euler–Lagrange equations are equivalent to the geodesic equation:

q¨α+Γβγαq˙βq˙γ=0

where

Γβγα=12gαρ(gβρ,γ+gγρ,β−gβγ,ρ),

with

gαβ,γ=∂gαβ∂qγ,

which is known as the Levi–Civita connection for the metric g .
Particle dynamics on such “curved” spaces appear both in general relativistic situations and also in cases such as vibrations on a bent sheet or other non-flat geometries.

2. Two coupled particles

(a)
Write the Lagrangian for two nonrelativistic particles with positions x1,x2 and equal mass m , moving in one dimension, connected by a spring whose force on x1 is

F1=−k(x1−x2−ℓ),

and whose force on x2 is

F2=−k(x2−x1+ℓ),

where ℓ is the unstretched length of the spring.
The momentum for particle i is the standard pi=mx˙i .
You may assume particle 1 is always to the right of particle 2.

(b)
Rewrite L in terms of the center of mass

X=12(x1+x2)

and the separation

x=x1−x2.

©
Solve the Euler–Lagrange equations in terms of X,x and show that they are equivalent to those in terms of x1,x2 .

Answers to Problem Set 1

I should note that the original answer doesn’t have description. The description here is generated by AI.

1. The Lagrangian and Geodesic Equation

(1.1) Generalized Momentum and Force

The Lagrangian is given by:

L=12gαβ(q)q˙αq˙β

The generalized momentum pα is defined as:

pα=∂L∂q˙α=12∂∂q˙α(gijq˙iq˙j)=12gij(δαiq˙j+q˙iδαj)=gαβ(q)q˙β.

The generalized force Fα is:

Fα=∂L∂qα=12∂gij(q)∂qαq˙iq˙j

Hence, pα corresponds to the momentum conjugate to qα , while Fα represents the generalized force arising from the variation of the metric tensor gαβ(q) .

(1.2) Derivation of the Geodesic Equation

We start from the Euler–Lagrange equation:

∂L∂qα=ddt∂L∂q˙α.

Substituting the expressions derived above:

12∂gij(q)∂qαq˙iq˙j=ddt(gαβ(q)q˙β)12∂gij∂qαq˙iq˙j=dgαβdtq˙β+gαβq¨β12∂gij∂qβq˙iq˙j=∂gβα∂qkq˙kq˙α+gβαq¨α.

Rearranging and multiplying by gαρ , we obtain:

12gαρ(∂gβγ∂qρq˙βq˙γ−2∂gγρ∂qβq˙βq˙γ)=q¨α.

Simplifying gives the standard geodesic form:

q¨α+12gαρ(−∂gβγ∂qρq˙βq˙γ+∂gγρ∂qβq˙βq˙γ+∂gβρ∂qγq˙βq˙γ)=0,

or equivalently,

q¨α+Γβγαq˙βq˙γ=0,

where

Γβγα=12gαρ(∂gρβ∂qγ+∂gργ∂qβ−∂gβγ∂qρ)

is the Levi–Civita connection.
Thus, the Euler–Lagrange equation for this Lagrangian indeed yields the geodesic equation.
Q.E.D.

2. Two Coupled Particles

(2.1) The Lagrangian in x1,x2

For two equal-mass particles connected by a spring:

F1=−k(x1−x2−ℓ),F2=−k(x2−x1+ℓ),

and the potential energy is:

U(x1,x2)=12k(x1−x2−ℓ)2.

Hence, the Lagrangian is:

L=12m(x˙12+x˙22)−12k(x1−x2−ℓ)2.

(2.2) Transformation to Center-of-Mass and Relative Coordinates

Define the center of mass and relative coordinate as:

X=12(x1+x2),x=x1−x2.

Then,

x˙1=X˙+12x˙,x˙2=X˙−12x˙.

Substituting these into L , we obtain:

L=12m[(X˙+12x˙)2+(X˙−12x˙)2]−12k(x−ℓ)2=14m(4X˙2+x˙2)−12k(x−ℓ)2.

Thus, the Lagrangian separates into center-of-mass motion and relative motion parts.

(2.3) Euler–Lagrange Equations and Equivalence

For each particle coordinate xi , the Euler–Lagrange equation is:

∂L∂xi=ddt∂L∂x˙i.

This gives:

∂L∂xi=Fi,ddt∂L∂x˙i=mx¨i.

Hence:

Fi=mx¨i.

Combining the two-particle equations yields:

0=m(x¨1+x¨2),−2k(x1−x2−ℓ)=m(x¨1−x¨2).

Now, in terms of X and x :

∂L∂X=0,∂L∂x=−k(x−ℓ),

and

ddt∂L∂X˙=2mX¨,ddt∂L∂x˙=12mx¨.

Thus, the corresponding Euler–Lagrange equations are:

−2mX¨=0⇒X¨=0,−k(x−ℓ)−12mx¨=0⇒mx¨=−2k(x−ℓ).

The first describes free motion of the center of mass,
and the second describes harmonic motion of the relative coordinate.

Q.E.D.
